metadata.name: Rule-Breaking Masterpieces Database
metadata.purpose: Reference for intentional musical rule-breaking with emotional justification
metadata.sources_added: Gemini 2.5 Pro research: Hooktheory, Open Music Theory, Ultimate Guitar, musicnotes, tapeop

master_principle.beethoven_quote: Well, who has forbidden them? Well, I allow them!
master_principle.philosophy: Rules exist for a reason, but the ultimate authority is your ear and your artistic intention

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Violins and violas moving in parallel P5 motion
rule_breaks.emotional_effect: Rustic, folk-like quality; evokes peasant dances
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Creates unified, raw sound that matches pastoral theme

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Planing - moving entire triads in parallel (C-E-G → D-F#-A → E-G#-B)
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Evokes pre-tonal organum; color over voice independence

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Root + P5 moving in parallel (E5→A5→D5)
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Distortion creates harmonics; 3rds create mud while P5s stay clear

rule_breaks.piece: The Rite of Spring - Augurs of Spring chord
rule_breaks.notation_detail: E♭7 (E♭-G-B♭-D♭) + E major (E-G#-B) simultaneously
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Neither key wins - represents pre-tonal ritual energy

rule_breaks.notation_detail: C major + F# major simultaneously (tritone root relationship)
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Maximum tonal distance; no common tones; represents split identity

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Semitone below 'correct' note (B♭ against B♮); major 2nd dyads that never resolve
rule_breaks.emotional_effect: Commentary on harmonic expectations; meaningful wrongness
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Wrong notes make sense BECAUSE they sound wrong in a meaningful way

rule_breaks.notation_detail: 26 chord changes in 16 bars; roots move by major 3rds (B→G→E♭); keys cycle every 2 beats
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Each V7 resolves but I immediately becomes passing tone to next key

rule_breaks.notation_detail: ♭VII in major keys (E-D-E = I-♭VII-I)
rule_breaks.why_it_works: ♭VII functions as dominant substitute; borrowed from Mixolydian

rule_breaks.rule_broken: Major and minor shouldn't mix freely
rule_breaks.notation_detail: G-B-C-Cm (I-III-IV-iv); B major from Lydian, Cm from parallel minor
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Conflates major and minor; proportion varies creating floating state

rule_breaks.notation_detail: I-♭VII-IV-I in G major (G-F-C-G); F major borrowed from G Mixolydian
rule_breaks.emotional_effect: Anthemic yearning, almost home but not quite
rule_breaks.why_it_works: ♭VII creates plagal-adjacent motion without full resolution; yearning quality

rule_breaks.notation_detail: I-♭VII-IV progression; ♭VII borrowed from Mixolydian
rule_breaks.why_it_works: ♭VII avoids dominant tension; creates suspended, floating quality

rule_breaks.notation_detail: I-V-vi-IV with ♭VI (A♭ in C major) at emotional peaks
rule_breaks.why_it_works: ♭VI borrowed from Aeolian creates unexpected darkness; hits harder because of major context

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Am-Em-Dm-G with F major (♭VI in Am); F borrowed from A natural minor
rule_breaks.why_it_works: ♭VI provides brief major-quality respite in minor key; creates push-pull of hope/despair

rule_breaks.notation_detail: i-♭VI-♭III-♭VII in B minor; multiple borrowed chords from Aeolian/Dorian
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Stacking borrowed chords creates modal ambiguity; neither major nor minor dominates

rule_breaks.rule_broken: Simple triads sufficient for emotional impact
rule_breaks.notation_detail: Chromatic descending bass: F-G-Am-C-Fm/Ab-Em/G-D9/F#. Uses Am7, Fadd9 instead of triads. F→Fm shift at emotional peak. Guitar tuned down whole step.
rule_breaks.emotional_effect: Hypnotic melancholy, whispered intimacy, sophisticated sadness
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Added tones (7ths, add9) create richer color. Descending bass creates gravity. Major-to-minor shift = resignation/dark acceptance.

rule_breaks.notation_detail: G-G/F#-Em7-D-C with descending bass. Unexpected E♭maj7 and Cm borrowed chords. Common tone G held across all changes.
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Common tone ties unrelated chords together. Descending bass = gentle falling. Minor plagal cadence (Cm→G) adds hopeful melancholy.

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Two nearly identical vocal takes panned L/R. Not harmony - texture. Close-miked whisper delivery.
rule_breaks.emotional_effect: Intimate presence, feeling of isolation, empathy for singer
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Tiny differences between takes create organic depth without artificial reverb. Feels like being in the room.

rule_breaks.piece: The Rite of Spring - Sacrificial Dance
rule_breaks.notation_detail: Alternating 2/16, 3/16, 5/16, 2/8, 3/8, 5/8, 7/8; additive rhythms
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Impossible to predict accent; evokes pre-civilized ritual

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Ambiguous meter (12/8? 4/4? 3/4+5/4?); piano chords with no discernible pulse
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Ambiguity is the point; meter only partially clarifies when drums enter

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Notes grouped in 5s and 7s because they don't fit 8ths, 16ths, or triplets
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Vertical improvisation tracing chord structures at blistering speed

rule_breaks.piece: Throughout piano works (e.g., Etude Op. 25 No. 1)
rule_breaks.notation_detail: Arpeggiated textures reveal parallel motion when notes gathered
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Piano sustain pedal and figuration mask voice-leading; different context than vocal music

rule_breaks.piece: Prelude in E Minor, Op. 28 No. 4
rule_breaks.notation_detail: m.23: Chord spelled as dominant 4/2 with B♭ bass; B♭ 'resolves' upward to B♮ across fermata silence
rule_breaks.emotional_effect: Negative action - gesture defined by NOT resolving
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Silence embodies the non-resolution; enharmonic ambiguity

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Am-F-C-G creates ambiguity between A minor and C major; neither asserts dominance
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Proportion of each mode varies; permanent ambiguity

rule_breaks.notation_detail: Riff built on G-G(octave)-D♭ (augmented 4th above G)
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Tension that begged resolution becomes genre identity; embraces 'devil's interval'

rule_breaks.piece: Standard jazz practice; Schubert String Quintet in C
rule_breaks.notation_detail: Replace G7 with D♭7 (tritone away) before C; both share same tritone (B-F)
rule_breaks.why_it_works: Shared tritone maintains harmonic function; bass moves chromatically

why_rule_breaking_works.explanation: Rules for polyphonic vocal music don't apply to distorted guitars or piano with sustain pedal
Wrong notes work because they're meaningfully wrong (Monk)
Parallel fifths evoke medieval music; polytonality evokes pre-tonal chaos
Ambiguity and non-resolution better express complex emotional states than clean resolution
Distortion, sustain, and electronics change which intervals work

recommended_techniques.application: F major surface with Am undertow; borrowed iv chord
recommended_techniques.emotional_justification: Creates misdirection - sounds like love until grief reveal
Nothing ever fully resolves after loss

specific_chord_options.effect: Sudden darkness, the reveal moment (All Too Well style)
specific_chord_options.use_at: The reveal line - 'when I found you sleeping'

specific_chord_options.effect: Unresolved, haunting end - never fully closes

specific_chord_options.technique: Bass walks down while chords stay related
specific_chord_options.effect: Gentle falling, emotional gravity, sophisticated sadness

specific_chord_options.technique: Add 7ths, use inversions for voice leading

production_techniques.how: Record soft vocal, record again nearly identical, pan 30% L/R
Mic 3-6 inches from source, capture breath and finger noise
Don't edit out breath, finger noise, slight timing variations

techniques_to_avoid.reason: Too on-the-nose dark; misdirection requires surface beauty
Too chaotic; Kelly song needs controlled surface
Too epic/anthemic; Kelly song is intimate bedroom emo
